Binomial experiment

A binomial experiment is a statistical experiment in which:

  • there are a fixed number of independenttrials.
  • there are only two possible results for each trial: success if some event occurs and failure if the event does not occur.
  • the probability of success in each trial is the same.

If \(X\) is the number of successes in a binomial experiment with \(n\) trials, each with probability of success \(p\), then \(X\) is called a binomial random variable. Note that here an independent trial is one where the outcome of one trial does not affect another. Thus, coin tosses are a binomial random variable but picking a coloured marble out of a bag with marbles of three colours is not a binomial random variable.


We can extend our observations of the coin toss experiment above to see that the probability of a binomial random variable is given by the following probability function. This is a function which tells us how to work out the probability of event \(x\) occurring.

Suppose that \(X\) is a binomial random variable with \(n\) independent trials and probability of success \(p\). The probability function of \(X\) is given by \[ p(x) = P(X = x) = {n \choose x} p^x (1-p)^{n-x}, \qquad \mbox{ where } x = 0,1,2,3,\dots \] Here, the \( {n \choose x} \) term represents the number of ways \(x\) successes can be ordered amongst the \(n\) trials and the \(p^x (1-p)^{n-x}\) is the probability of obtaining \(x\) successes and \(n-x\) failures in a particular order.

The probability distribution of \(X\) is called the Binomial distribution and we write \[ X \sim B(n,p). \]
